comment_text:
I would like to point out several things:
1. Luke Talley is awesome.
2. Every single frame of this video requires more memory storage than this memory module is capable of handling. Think about that.
3. On the second channel we talk about things like how they took into account gyroscopic precession with this bad boy. They also crashed this into the moon and used the signal as a way to figure out what the inside of the moon is like. It's a good video, you should consider watching it. ( https://youtu.be/6mMK6iSZsAs )
4. This is not the Apollo computer. This is the Saturn V computer. They're different. This steered the rocket.
5. People that support Smarter Every Day on Patreon are really cool and I like them a lot. ( https://www.patreon.com/smartereveryday )

typically it was women who were best at this with more delicate fingers. The wires threaded thru the cores were spot welded to a stiff piece of wire that was the leader for the copper wire that remained in the core. somewhat like miniature fishtape for number 32 enabled copper wire. They also used a ring type desk lamp with a magnifying lens to see the work better.

That's amazing. We are standing on the shoulders of those women who did that precise and tedious task and everyone else who was involved in manufacturing those computers. Their hard work is so valuable and has set us up to thrive and live life with more rich experiences.
News flash! Core memory shown is still used today in military aircraft etc because it is impervious to emp. And yes, there are people still threading these albeit they are mostly older and retiring.
So fascinating!  I always wondered about the computers they used. It exceeded my imagination.

I remember someone telling me that a modern (young) hardware engineer would barely recognise the Saturn V computer (LVDC) or the Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC) as a computer, particularly the rope memory. This video is something of a proof ...

I'm taking a minute to ponder just how polarizing the perception of Talley's explanation must be. I can't imagine that it is anything less than dreadfully boring to most people and then for people who clicked on the video it is absolutely exhilarating to hear about crawling around on your knees with a paper template looking for patterns of useful information.
This was the video that introduced me to Linus tech tips and my subsequent computer tech obsession. Thanks for doing this Collab Dustin!! 😁

There was a point in Luke's commentary that I suddenly realised that I had a huge grin on my face because I had been completely blown away by what he was saying.  It reminded me that way back at the end of 1981 I had one of the first BBC Micro computers — mine had the serial number 00050.  I chose to go big, so I had 16kb memory.  What amazes me thinking back on it, is what was possible with so little memory.  It ran a decent version of Space Invaders and an OK word processor.  My current system has 64gb RAM and is five years old!
You know Linus is famous for having butter fingers and  being clumsy, don't you??!!!😃 Wrong person to hold the rare NASA computer with all respect!!! Hehehehe

This is interesting since I worked on computers (IBM 360 types) in the 70's.  Didn't have core memory, but had punch cards, and programs were loaded by cassette tapes, and our front-end processors were lucky to have 1Meg of memory (solid state at that time) which took up a lot of space All the circuitry was TTL. So this predates that, but we learned about it.

We used 8 Honeywell CCC machines running in parallel to run the Apollo Command Module simulator down in Houston. I worked with Luke Talley at IBM-Charlotte during the mid to late 1980's.  As a young engineer, I was enthralled by his stories of the space program.  A few years ago, I was visiting my son in Huntsville where he works as an aerospace engineer and we decided to go to the Space and Rocket Center.   While touring the Saturn-V, I told my son about Luke and related a story Luke told about firing the F-1 engines.  A few minutes later, we arrived at the instrument ring and there stood Luke.  I hadn't seen him in 25 years but he hadn't changed much.  He was as sharp as ever.

2 things I found funny. One, the director not knowing the basic background of the women would worked on building the memory cores. I would think that bit of information would be relevant. You would think since in the past 10 years with talks, documentaries, books and movies that have come out about women being a fundamental part of NASA, as well mas the computer field. Like for example, the ENIAC computers that were used during the Manhattan Project to calculate the amount of nuclear material needed to built the first atomic bombs, for example, women mathematicians were the ones that did the actual program of the UNIVAC switches. Which this goes to the 2nd thing that made me laugh was when Linus made the comment about that the women who did the threading of the memory bits had a textile background. Wonderful video. I am a retired ( three years) Boeing engineering technical fellow in high speed digital electronics. Before Boeing I designed supercomputers. I say bring me a digital deign problem that happens in a billionth if a second and we’ll go fix it. I remember seeing  core memories on Interdata microcomputers. It was pretty antiquated in the mid seventies though. Dynamic RAM was just in its infancy. Instead of magnetic cores you charged semiconductor capacitors. Again though the act of reading destroyed the data and you had to design rewrite logic. I also remember vividly July 20th 1969 and the moon landing. I was a junior in high school and going to summer school at UC Santa Barbara. What fun. I had a good friend who worked for Boeing in Huntsville during the 60s designing the first stage.He helped design the cooling for the rocket nozzles. We talked shop on a regular basis. Sadly he passed away last week. I loved this video. Thanks.

I like hearing Luke talk about the computer system and its core memory. I'd love to meet Luke. I've got two PDP-8 family computers with core memory that I get to take care of and feed. And repair when something fails. ;) So far, as far as I know, my core memory is still good. I also found a "tin" of cores on eBay and took it to work to share the "bits" with co-workers (Engineers) who thought it was cool/amazing to see & hold individual bits.
Luke's analysis of the octal dumps is familiar too. I had the "privilege" of learning to read a papertape to determine what the work computer's code should have been and single-stepping through the entire core to make corrections as needed. Not quite the same as what Luke was doing, but similar. And I'm a Mechanical Engineer, not a Computer/Electrical Engineer, so it was quite a learning experience and why I've adopted the PDP-8s. ;)

I am a Tool & Die maker/mold maker/engine builder/machine builder/house builder that recently retired. (I'm 63 now)
Back in 1977, I was 20. I machined the copper venturi for the Lunar Lander. Aerojet Rocketdyne on Long Island, N.Y. sub contracted these engines to us at Atlantic Tool & Die in South Plainfield, N.J. where I'm from. I was an apprentice at that time and remembered that I would have not been able to touch it unless I was on a certified apprenticeship. I was not allowed to finish it, but I did rough machine the 18" long venturi in a Monarch Tracer lathe. I just wanted to share some of my experience that I had back in the day. Also, I enjoyed the interview with Tory Bruno in another video was nourishing my brain. What a great human being.

Awesome stuff. But I wonder how many here recall that ALL of this telecommunications technology of nothing more than moving One's & Zero's around in company with basic software to interpret the data was in fact based upon an even more fundamental technology that few remember. Certainly not, it seems, by those who created this YoutTube video. What is it that's even used today by most everyone nowadays in their everyday lives?

Why Morse Code of course! The first ever form of basic digital communications over long distances (using either HF Radio and/or early submarine cables running telegraph signals - ie simply transmitting/receiving One's & Zero's - dots & dashes) that progressively morphed into improved, higher data rates & ever increasing signalling systems that we know today & common throughout the digital world - eg; where would our mobile phone technology be without it!.

Memories, memories for an old Morse Operator who still has, and can also use, his Morse Code key.

5:55 I just love - love - when museums employ (or bring on as volunteers) people who were directly involved with a museum's subject matter.
I recently visited the US again, this time LA and Sand Diego. I visited the La Brea Tar Pits Museum, and had the chance to speak with paleontologists and conservationists firsthand about their work. I visited the LA Science Centre, where the Endeavour space shuttle now resides, and spoke at length with an attendant about the shuttle's operation, spaceLAB, and the privatisation of space programs. Most memorably, I visited the USS Midway and had the privilege and the pleasure to listen to and speak with many, many retired pilots and operators about the various jet fighters on the carriers as well as the procedure of getting fighters up in the air and back down safely. It was incredible. having these people making themselves available, happy to come every day and speak about their experiences, was so enriching.

Making a core memory was greatly facilitated by the Core Loading Plates that Hutchinson Technology made for all the memory makers. A core loading plate had thousands of tiny slots, one slot for each a small donut-shaped core, all aligned according to the design of the plane. A plate was made as a stack of photo-etched foils, all laminated to make a plate up to ~ 12 x 12 x 1/16" thick. Each layer was different to make a nest for the cylindrical core with generous corner relief so as not to trap a core. Lower layers had a smaller circular vacuum hole to pull the core into place.


To fill the late it was put in a vibrating fixture that applied vacuum. Then an excess of cores was poured over the plate surface and the cores fell or were sucked into place. Any extra cores were gently brushed away with a fine brush, and the cores were transferred onto a tacky foam, ready to be strung with the wires.


All this was clean room work requiring the utmost in precision and defect elimination.

In the 1970's I WORKED on the Burroughs 3500 series MAINFRAME computer systems. Install & maintain. They had 30K Core memory 'stacks'. EXTREMELY reliable. Note: in real life there were many, not just 2, wires that ran though each core. The X and the Y current lines, each carried only 1/2 the current necessary to 'flip' a core. These ran in a matrix 'diagonally' across the core stack. Only the chosen core got both currents (enough to cause a flip if it wasn't already in that state). Then the sense line, it ran though all the 1's or 2' or 4's, (etc) and would sense if ANY bit in that plane flipped. Then there was the X and the Y 'Inhibit" lines that ran diagonally across the stack and ran current in the opposite direction to the X and Y lines, in the bit planes not to be sensed to prevent the other bits from flipping in that bit plane. That's 5 wires though EACH core!
1st computer I was the maintenance engineer on had 180K of 'system memory', 6 'stacks'. It ran an entire Air Force base, about 40 terminals plus batch processing on many programs in the computer itself.


In 7 years of running 24 X 7, about 4 systems (you add up the hours) I only had 1 failure, and it was a matrix transformer that fed current though one of the inhibit wires. BTW, the inhibit lines ran at 26 volts.

Core memory requires a destructive read. To read a bit, you write a "0" into it. If it doesn't draw any current, it was already a "0" and then you conclude it is a "0.". If it does draw current, it was a "1," and then you have to restore it by writing a "1." Make sense?

When we think of computers today we think in terms of all programming done through a general purpose computer with microprocessors.  Designs in the 50s and 60s relied more on highly optimized logic, and by logic I don't mean a CPU.  Logic included circuits designed to do or test a specific thing.  Analog logic was also part of a complete system.  Now where you run everything through a DSP you don't have to think as much in terms of analog circuits but at the time analog circuits were an art form of their own.  Different times using solutions optimized with what they had to work with at that time.  Very impressive.

Linus seems amazed with the read/rewrite process of core memory, but it only sounds exceedingly complex because in those days engineers had to write their own drivers, doing it "manually" so to speak. A much more complicated process goes on with the SDRAM he works with routinely, but because it happens automatically (chances are he doesn't even have to configure memory timings manually in BIOS like we used to in the old days) he doesn't think about it. Today I own a phone which could handle ALL the calculations, both at NASA and on Apollo 11, with one one arm tied behind it's back. My hat  is off to the engineers and mathematicians who guided Apollo to it's lunar landing and back home safely. The advances in my life time alone (and I am only 64) are absolutely amazing. At 2:00, you are describing "core" memory, which was the type of memory used in most computers up to around 1975-1980, when semiconductor memory first entered the scene. I worked on an IBM 1620, a 1401 and others, including a minicomputer made by a company called Microdata, which all used core memory. (I'm 72.)

I still have three 8K memory boards from that Microdata computer. (Failure of this type of memory was common, so I decided to save boards when they were replaced.) I remember they were priced at $3,500 each back then, or around 5 cents/bit. At that rate, 16GB of RAM (128 billion bits), now commonplace in PC's, would cost 6.4 billion dollars (without accounting for inflation)! That's over double the entire Apollo program budget. (Good thing they didn't need 16GB.)

Just as shown in this video, I can see the little cores arranged on the grid of wires. I was amazed back then, and I still find it impressive today. Here's an interesting fact about core memory: In order to read a bit, the computer would actually write a zero at that location. A sense wire running through all the bits on that plane would detect a pulse if that location originally contained a 1 because reversing the magnetic direction would induce that electric pulse. A second cycle was then required to restore the bit back to a 1 (or leave it as 0 if no pulse was detected). This was known as "destructive" read, requiring two machine cycles. One cycle on the Microdata was one microsecond (1 MHz). A modern CPU running at 4GHz is 4,000 times faster. But one cool thing: if the computer lost power, core memory was preserved! It wasn't 100% reliable, but often, when the computer was powered back on after a power failure, it could continue running where it left off!

Anyway, I am wondering what to do with these memory boards. Right now, they're just gathering dust in my closet. Any ideas?

I'm 61. I was there watching in real time the launch of Apollo 11. Then a decade later I gained a friend that worked for Western Union. He showed me there facility. Around 1980. They had 3 of the same model IBM computers that was used to launch the Apollo ship just to handle telegrams and showed me one one of those core memory boards. When one would fail, there was a husband and wife team that would fly out and replace that tiny ferrous core in the weave. They got paid 20 grand to do it. So I was told.


Now in your computer. You have a failed 4 Gigabyte memory, had to spell it out, "card/stick"...... You replace, it at a cost less than 100 bucks.

There have been a lot of videos posted recently regarding the 50th anniversary of Apollo 11. In another video (I'm sorry I don't remember where) they were talking about the Apollo guidance computer that was in the command module. It also talked about the core memory being hand wired. That video implied that the actual data was encoded in the wiring patterns. Such that if you wanted a bit "ON" you wire it one way and if you wanted a bit "OFF" you wired it a different way. I did not believe that for a minute. I was a computer science student in the early 70s in the days when mainframe computers had iron core memory and I knew that it was a programmable memory and not a ROM. It's hard enough to wire up those cores but the idea that they were looking at some sort of data dump with binary code and hardwiring the data into the cores seemed ridiculous to me. Your revelation that each time you read one of the cores you had to rewrite it to re-magnetize the core confirms for me but also this was mostly a read-only memory, that the actual program was not physically hardwired into it but was somehow programmed into it like a ROM memory. Can you confirm that the cores were all wired identically and then somehow programmed once assembled and that the program itself was not handwoven into the hardware?

All of this type of video merely illustrate how far technology has come since 1969, and thus the ever growing question of why exactly ZERO people have made it past LEO since these stories of them doing so.

Remarkable luck I saw this in my feed. The ferrite core memory being described around 9:20 was invented by our former neighbour in England, Dr. Ron Millership, back in the 50s. (US Patent US2790160A) Lovely American bloke who in the 1980s would invite my brother and I over and tell us about his work, over a stiff drink. Both he and his English wife passed away years ago, but both very kind. His invention was ground breaking because it introduced solid state non volatile memory. Until then, digital memory was either based on mechanical physical media (cards, tape etc) or constantly refreshed solid state memory that of course required constant power.
It was inventions like Ron's that in part made the early space program possible.
Thanks for the video, makes me honored to know Ron although he doesn't get much coverage anywhere, probably because he was an employee of IBM, not sure.

US Navy Data Systems tech 1982-2005. First mainframe (UNIVAC CP-642B) I maintained used core memory. Ours had 4 wires: x, y, sense and inhibit. Read to zeroes, write to ones. The sense line indicated where a change had occurred, and the inhibit was for a location that was a zero and writing a one needed to be inhibited. We even had an Extended Core Memory Unit (ECMU) to allow us 500KB of additional program memory.

Years ago , I watched dozens of women thread the core memory grid's at a company named "Fabri-tek" in Eau Claire , Wisconsin.

They were looking thru large specialized microscopes, and had plenty of good lighting for each person threading the beads. This was in about 1964-65 . I was a young tech college electronics theory/technology instructor, and the visit was part of a tour for electronics instructors, statewide in Wisc. There are 3- hair -like wires going thru each "doughnut". "Read wire", "write wire", and "sense wire" or core location. (address) each wire a different color. Was beyond amazing that many years ago.

Now, I'm 77, and retired. I wonder how much memory is in my heart pacemaker? LOL.

I have a Burroughs Computer 480 bit core memory frame similar to the one shown in the video above. A few years ago, with my 12 year old nephew, calculated how big his 8 gig iPod would need to be using that core technology.....Just the memory alone would take up something like 17 football fields of area. I forgot how much it would weigh but it was many, many tons! That also does not include the small power station that would be needed to power it.


My nephew shrugged his shoulders and then slipped his iPod back into his pocket!

In a reference to that debugging situation the IBM engineer talked about: One of my first computer tasks out of college (1977) was to read a very old magnetic tape by hand, yep by HAND. The tape was so old we could not find anybody in the UK who had an operational mag tape drive that could read it. The data was VERY important so we "read" it by using a magnifying glass and a special magnetic ink that we painted onto the tape which showed the magnetization pattern which we then wrote down and then later transferred to punched card and finally read into by an IBM mainframe. Even though we got pretty good at reading the tape it took forever to "read" the file (weeks). I don't think my eyes were ever the same......

Ah yes the good old days!

You relly need to differentiate between RAM and ROM.
What you had and what you observed through the lens was RAM.
ROM worked differently. It also used magentized rings, but if the programm demanded a 1, then the "read wire" went through the ring and when the programm demanded a zero the read wire passed around the ring. The way it worked was that a pulse was sent in on the column and row adress lines while at the same time watching the read wire, if the magnetic ring induced a pulse in the read wire. If you allow me to fomulate it sloppy, each ROM core ring worked like a small transformer. If the read wire passed though the transformer, the magnetic field induced a current in the wire, if the wire did not pass through the transformer, no current was induced.

This reminds me of Naval radar school and a particular piece of gear called the "AGE" which stood for ancillary government equipment. The AGE was about the size of a suitcase and opened from the front on a piano hinge in the back to reveal two halves full of thousands of wire wrapped square posts. Each post was wired to a magnetic core in memory.

Each core had three wires in it. One for read, one for write, and the third for sense. The sense wire was connected to an LED on the front side of the AGE. Each LED was a test point in the radar equipment. So the theory was that with a quick visual scan of the AGE, one could confirm whether the radar was working properly or malfunctioning and if it was malfunctioning, give the technician (like me) an idea of exactly where the fault was!

During school on radar equipment while I was using this AGE, I spotted a fault that the instructors had not installed for me to find. The fault that I found, had been caused by instructors repeatedly installing a different particular fault in the particular piece of gear I was working on! They originally were going to fail me on this until I insisted they double check my troubleshooting with measurements of their own. They agreed and I was right. They later told me that, that was the first time in the radar school's history that that had happened!

Obviously, I passed radar technician school. But at the time, there was no Bell Curve grading! You either passed or failed! It wasn't like you could skate by on a "70%" and call it a day. I was getting upset that the instructors were going to initially fail me on that test until my insistance that I was right caused them to take a closer look themselves!

The fault that I found was related to the generation of a 30 microsecond blanking gate signal for the radar receiver.

There is a sidelight to core memory a lot of folks have never heard of. You spoke of conventional core memory, where X and Y axis wires can be energized to impose a magnetic orientation on a single iron core. A single sense wire passed through all the cores, so writing an opposite value produced an induced spike on the sense wire. Bits were read by writing a known value and watching for the induced kick. No kick, the value was what you wrote, got a kick, you destructively changed what was there.

But that's not the end of it. Apollo guidance computers used memory modules that stored four bits per each individual core. You could correctly argue that's impossible for read-write memory, but the rope core memory wasn't read-write, it was read-only.

Instead of high magnetic permeability iron beads (cores), they used permanent magnets. Instead of one sense wire, they used four.

All the magnets were physically oriented the same way. When a particular X and a particular Y wire were energized, you got (or didn't get) spikes on each of the four sense wires. The data was encoded by the weave - if a sense wire went through a core at a particular grid location, it represented a one. If it skipped that core, that location was interpreted as a zero. Each tiny bit had X and Y wires passing through it, and also had up to four sense wires. Energize X and Y for a particular location, read four bits simultaneously. Since the cores were permanent magnets, the write operations weren't destructive.

Countless such examples of design creativity hallmark the Apollo project. It's overwhelmingly sad when people say we never went to the moon. Of course, it's usually people who can't balance a checkbook and will never recognize the courage it took to light 7.5 million pounds of thrust, entrusting slide rules and three digits of precision with human lives.

Of course, that wasn't really how it worked. It wasn't the primitive computers or the slide rules that safely returned astronauts from where no man had gone before. It was willpower, determination, curiosity, and discipline. Humankind at its finest.

Back in 1969, I was on a student training program with the Dutch company Philips, whose factory in the UK (Mullards) manufactured these core memory modules. I remember being warned by a very stern Union official not to go onto the factory floor, since it wasn't safe for a 'young lad' to be where literally hundreds of woman painstakingly threading those miniscule ferrite cores! Of course we went anyway. It was the most intense atmosphere but I do recall the relaxing music they played to keep those woman sane. Sadly that huge factory is long gone now. It's all just rows little houses now.

Humbling accomplishments

in '69 i took my first two courses in programming, the first, fortran IV, and the second, IBM assembler.  we had access to one of the largest mainframes around at the time.  each undergrad was allocated 16k of RAM to execute our programs.  it was way more than we needed to do a tree sort, or various and sundry mathematical problems.  besides assignments, some of us amused ourselves by writing programs that played games like subhunt or pocket billiards.  the professor had a whopping 64k of RAM allocated to his acct, and using it, he wrote a chess program able to beat the average college student.  so forgive me if i call EVERYTHING today bloatware.

A dear friend of my stepmother (both now long departed) used to work for Litton, I believe.  She received more than one monthly award for producing the most error-free core memory assemblies.  Yes, we humans really CAN do such work by hand.  I was also privileged to visit NASA's Plum Brook research station in the early 1980's, to do some work re-purposing the immense vacuum chamber used to test fire the engines on the LEM in a real, hard vacuum.  The workmanship at that entire facility was stellar, to say the least.  The entire nation took immense pride in every aspect of the Apollo missions, and it showed.

I'm surprised that Linus was surprised to learn that the process of reading ferrite core memory is destructive. Guess what? DRAM reads are also destructive. Every time the bit is read from the modern DRAM, it gets destroyed. DRAM controller then restores it back after reading. However, unlike ferrite core, DRAM is very volatile, so DRAM controller has to read and refresh it every 64 milliseconds. Linus should know it, right? Why was he so surprised then?

We had similar memory in a air traffic radar processing computer. It had about 1mb of core memory and could process all the radar information for 125 air traffic controllers. The most amazing thing was how many algorithms we’d do in software today were hard wired into the machine. Yes, hard wired sort and filter algorithms. Not very flexible but amazingly fast and efficient. Truly some amazing engineering. We also had a similar process to Luke’s for troubleshooting, except we got hex dump.

Linus is awesome, and honestly I probably spend more time on youtube watching LTT videos than anything else... However... Linus isn't a computer engineer, and as much as I think he is savvy enough to appreciate all this, I don't think Dustin had it right in thinking this would in any way be an 'interesting exchange.' Simply put Linus has very little to offer in a discussion like this. Being familiar with computers and modern technology is not the same thing as having an in depth technical familiarity with the detailed design of computer hardware.

Most of the tech journalists including LTT, GN, R2C, et cetera are all competent and have connections with industry professionals at intel, AMD, and NvIdia who might appreciate this and be able to have a true detailed discussion that would be amazing, but these are people they are connected with, not the journalists themselves. At the end of the day, a cool video, but I feel like it would have been almost the exact same video without Linus holding the priceless piece of American history adding to the tension given his history with valuable parts....
